templateAssets.content:
This agreement displays all lower-division courses required in the major: Stanislaus State courses or requirements on the left, approved (articulated) transfer courses on the right.


Helpful resources:

Academic Catalog

Transfer Admissions


Questions regarding this agreement may be directed to the Stanislaus State Articulation Analyst. Please visit the Stanislaus State Articulation Website for contact information.

Certain lower division courses in the areas of study must be repeated for credit. The repeated lower division courses for each area are as follows:

  • Piano Performance:
  • MUS 1611 and MUS 2611 must be repeated for a total of 2 units each
  • Instrumental Performance:
  • MUS 1671 and MUS 2671 must be repeated for a total of 2 units each
  • Vocal Performance:
  • MUS 1641 and MUS 2641 must be repeated for a total of 2 units each
  • MUS 2923 (or the upper division MUS 4923) must be repeated for a total of 3 units
  • Jazz Performance:
  • MUS 1671 and MUS 2671 must be repeated for a total of 2 units each
  • MUS 2501 (and/or the upper division MUS 4501) must be repeated for a total of 4 units

templateAssets.content:
Under the direction of the major advisor, students must complete one of the major areas of study:

  • Piano Performance
  • Instrumental Performance
  • Vocal Performance
  • Music Education - Instrumental or Choral
  • Composition
  • Jazz Performance


Lower division major courses for each area of study are listed below. Please refer to the Music B.M. program page of the Academic Catalog for more information.

attributes.content: Please refer to additional important General Information section above
Please refer to additional important General Information section above

templateAssets.content:
The Bachelor of Music is an intensive curriculum designed for students wishing to prepare for graduate study in music and for specific professional purposes. Degree majors include instrumental and choral music education (credential preparation), instrumental, vocal, and piano performance, composition, and jazz studies.


The Bachelor of Music degree is a four-year course of study culminating in the presentation of a solo recital or the completion of a faculty-approved project. Following the junior qualifying examination at the final 2000-level jury, the faculty will determine whether the student should pursue the Recital Track or the Project Track. Refer to the Music B.M. program page for more information on the individual Tracks and their requirements.


View information for the Department of Music, including Learning Objectives for the department and its programs.

Transfer students entering the music major must be evaluated by the Department before registering for their first semester on campus. Depending upon audition results, one to four units of lower division applied study and/or lower division Major Repertoire may be waived.
